docs.lead_paragraph: Saying it would be irresponsible and dishonest for any presidential candidate to take a ''no new taxes'' pledge, former Senator Bill Bradley refused today to rule out raising taxes to pay for his plan to make health insurance available to almost every American. But Mr. Bradley, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination, said he did not think a tax increase would be necessary to pay for the $65-billion-a-year proposal because of the nation's robust economy and a projected $1 trillion surplus, which he says is large enough to finance the plan over the coming decade.

headline.main: Bradley Says Ruling Out A Tax Hike Is Dishonest

docs.abstract: Bill Bradley, campaigning in Iowa, says it would be irresponsible and dishonest for any presidential candidate to take 'no new taxes' pledge; refuses to rule out raising taxes to pay for his plan to make health insurance available to almost every American; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Life Insurance Company, the seventh-largest life insurer in the United States, said yesterday that it would pay $570 million to acquire Mexico's third-largest insurer, Seguros Monterrey Aetna S.A., from Grupo Financiero Bancomer S. A. and Aetna Inc. to expand its business in Mexico. Bancomer, Mexico's second-largest banking group, said it would receive $290 million for its 51 percent stake in the insurance venture. New York Life gains a subsidiary that sells life, health, property and casualty policies in a growing insurance market where insurance premiums proportional to economic output are less than in other Latin American countries. Aetna rose $1.8125, to $59.5625. Seguros Monterrey has 23 percent of Mexico's individual life insurance business.

headline.main: NEW YORK LIFE TO ACQUIRE MEXICAN INSURER

docs.snippet: The New York Life Insurance Company, the seventh-largest life insurer in the United States, said yesterday that it would pay $570 million to acquire Mexico's third-largest insurer, Seguros Monterrey Aetna S.A., from Grupo Financiero Bancomer S. A....

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton will order federal agencies that provide or finance health care to take steps to reduce medical errors blamed for tens of thousands of deaths, administration officials said today. The order would require pharmacists to take more precautions to avoid dispensing the wrong drugs and would encourage hospitals to investigate errors that cause serious injuries or deaths and report their findings to state health agencies. The standards would apply to health care providers under direct federal control, but would serve as an example for the rest of the industry.

headline.main: A Clinton Order Seeks to Reduce Medical Errors

docs.abstract: Administration officials say Pres Clinton will order federal agencies that provide or finance health care to take steps to reduce medical errors blamed for tens of thousands of deaths; order will require pharmacists to take more precautions to avoid dispensing wrong drugs and will encourage hospitals to investigate errors that cause serious injuries or deaths and report their findings to state health agencies; standards will apply to health care providers under direct federal control, but will serve as example for rest of industry; Pres Clinton has decided to accept major recommendations from National Academy of Sciences report that says medical mistakes could be reduced by half in next five years if health care providers collected and analyzed data on unsafe practices (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was probably inevitable that the World Wide Web would bloom with sites for dieters. But to the surprise of professional dietitians, many of these sites have turned out to be not only popular but effective. From fee-based ventures like eDiets.com to free ones like Cyberdiet.com, a cornucopia of sites has sprung up in the last year or two to provide nutrition and diet advice. Many offer services that are otherwise found through private dietitians or diet companies like Weight Watchers, including personalized feedback and support from a group of fellow dieters.

headline.main: Losing Pounds by Surfing, on the Web

docs.abstract: Comment on dieting sites that have sprung up on World Wide Web; among most aggressive commercial dieting sites is eDiets.com; site offers advice on nutrition, exercise and motivation for a fee; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: They are profiles in decency, these men who want to be president. They lounge in sweaters and open-neck shirts, waxing heroic about their victories over the H.M.O.'s. They unwind in diners with demographically correct cross-sections of American voters, laying out proposals for lifting the tax burden on middle-class families. They stride purposefully with their wives, chatter meaningfully with well-wishers and, oh, yes, kiss and fuss over any child they come across. New Hampshire's airwaves are crackling with the give-and-take of campaign advertising. A rotating cycle of about 15 advertisements is being broadcast, with new ones being added all the time. But judging from this growing batch, the race for the nominations is not so much a rough-and-tumble sweepstakes as a contest to see who can hug the hardest. The tone in the spate of spots by the front-runners in both parties is generically folksy and upbeat: the candidates have not only not gone negative, they have gone all warm and fuzzy.

headline.main: In New Hampshire Ads, an Audible Warmth

docs.abstract: New Hampshire's airwaves crackle with give-and-take of presidential campaign advertising; spots project audible warmth instead of political broadsides, suggesting that race for nominations is not so much rough-and-tumble sweepstakes as contest to see who can hug hardest; ads by frontrunners in both parties are generically folksy and upbeat--projecting warmth and fuzziness rather than being negative (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The budget bill signed last week by President Clinton is packed with provisions sought by lobbyists for drug companies, hospitals, health maintenance organizations and nursing homes. Congress backed away from any broad overhaul of Medicare and rebuffed older patients' pleas for coverage of prescription drugs, but it tinkered with details of the program -- details that determine how billions of dollars are spent each year. Many provisions follow the lobbyists' recommendations word for word.

headline.main: Health Industry Sees Wish List Made Into Law

docs.abstract: Budget bill signed by Pres Clinton is packed with provisions sought by lobbyists for drug companies, hospitals, health maintenance organizations and nursing homes; even though Congress backed away from any broad overhaul of Medicare, it tinkered with details of program in way that could determine how billions of dollars are spent each year; many provisions follow lobbyists recommendations, word for word (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LESS than a month after the last workers at the former Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company headquarters in downtown Newark packed up and left, a new single tenant, International Discount Telecommunications, began moving into the 20-story building. IDT, a provider of high-speed Internet access and discount long distance telephone service, signed on to lease the 450,000-square-foot structure at 520 Broad Street as its world headquarters on Nov. 19, a Friday. That weekend it began relocating about 100 of its 1,100 workers to the building from Hackensack, replacing the insurer, which had ceased operations last summer.

headline.main: In the Region/New Jersey; An Added Anchor for Newark's Downtown Revival

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Bill Schwartz likes to think of the Samaritan House clinic as a model of inefficiency. The small clinic for the poor in this Bay area suburb is so heavily staffed that doctors can take half an hour to talk casually with patients about a backache. They hang out in the office reading medical journals. They chat with each other in the hallways. There are almost always more doctors on hand than are needed. How do they manage to do this in the age of managed care? Dr. Schwartz and his colleagues possess the one thing that other doctors, indeed most professionals, lack nowadays: time. They are all retired volunteers.

headline.main: Many Retirees Find It's Time to Go to Work

docs.abstract: Retired doctors volunteeer their services at Samaritan House clinic in San Mateo, Calif, freed from constraints of managed care and able to practice medicine as they were trained to practice it half a century ago in the age of house calls; represent new generation of older people who refused to go quietly to pasture and who are demanding a vital role in American life; recent poll of Americans age 50 to 75 found that only 28 percent of them embrace the traditional view of retirement as a time to take it easy and enjoy leisure activities; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ASIDE from driving to work and perhaps breaking for lunch, what do more than 90 percent of private-sector employees in this country have in common? The answer: They are not union members. The A.F.L.-C.I.O., groggily awakening to its increasing irrelevance, has lately been calling for stepped-up organizing efforts. But it might as well lobby for a ban on fax machines, for all the good it will do.

headline.main: A New Idea For Unions: Forget the Past

docs.lead_paragraph: Hip-Hop Honors WEDNESDAY -- L L Cool J will pay tribute to Russell Simmons, the hip-hop music and entertainment producer and chief executive of Rush Communications, and Lyor Cohen, a co-president of Island/Def Jam Music Group, at the UJA-Federation of New York's annual Spirit of Music dinner. The black-tie event, to be held under the tent on West 62nd Street across from Lincoln Center, begins with cocktails at 6:30 and will raise money for the UJA-Federation and its New York Music for Youth Foundation. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 836-1853.
